review.title: Statistical Cost Sharing
review.abstract: We study the cost sharing problem for cooperative games in situations where the cost function $C$ is not available via oracle queries, but must instead be derived from data, represented as tuples $(S, C(S))$, for different subsets $S$ of players. We formalize this approach, which we call statistical cost sharing, and consider the computation of the core and the Shapley value, when the tuples are drawn from some distribution $\mathcal{D}$.

metadata.title: Statistical Cost Sharing

sections.text: Previous work by Balcan et al. [8] in this setting showed how to calculate cost ratios that most likely fulfill the core property for limited function classes. We deepen their work and specify an algorithm that calculates such cost ratios for each function with a non-empty core. We supplement these results by showing an approximate lower limit for weaker relaxation. We then turn our attention to the Shapley value. First, we show that if cost functions come from the family of submodular functions with limited curvature, the Shapley value can be estimated from samples to a given factor, and that the limit is narrow. Then, we define statistical analogies of the Shapley axioms and derive an idea of the statistical Shapley value. We show that these values for general functions can be arbitrarily approximated across any distribution.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Cost-sharing requires an equitable way of distributing the cost of a service among all parties involved. Formally, there is a cost-sharing function defined across all segments of a set of elements (or players), and the goal is to share the cost of the entire bandwidth fairly between participants. However, cost-sharing is central to cooperative game theory, and there is a rich literature that develops the key terms and principles on the subject. While both the core and the Shapley value are easy to define, calculating them presents additional challenges when no group of players has an incentive to distract, and the Shapley value [39], which represents the unique vector of cost-sharing that fulfils four natural axioms, is to define both Shapley values easily; it establishes that calculating cost-sharing is involved in costs requires knowledge of costs in myriads of different scenarios.

Our main result is an algorithm that generalizes these results for all games in which the core is not empty and we derive sample complexity limits that show exactly the number of samples needed to calculate cost proportions (theorems 3 and 5).1 While the main approach of Balcan et al. sections.heading: 2.1 The core
sections.text: The core is a balanced cost allocation where no actor has an incentive to deviate from the Grand Coalition - for each subset of actors, the sum of their shares does not cover their collective costs.Definition 1. Cost allocation is at the core of function C if the following characteristics are met: • Balance: • i-N-i = C (N), • Core property: for all S'N-i-S-i ≤ C (S).The core is a natural cost-sharing concept. For example, in the battery blame scenario, such a guarantee means the following assurance: no matter what other apps run at the same time, an app will never be held responsible for more battery consumption than if it runs alone. Given that app developers are typically business competitors and that the battery of a mobile device is a very scarce resource, such a guarantee can pretty accurately avoid a large amount of blame. Unfortunately, for a certain cost function C the core may not exist (say that the core is empty), or may be multiple (there may be).

sections.text: We turn our attention to the STATISTICAL COST SHARING problem in the context of the Shapley value. Since the properties (axioms) of the Shapley value are above elements and not propositions, there is no simple approximation of the Shapley value where the properties are "likely" above D as we had them for the core. However, since the Shapley value exists for all functions and is unique, natural relaxation is only an approximation of this value from the samples. We begin with the observation that there is a distribution that Shapley value can be estimated arbitrarily well from samples. However, in this work we are motivated by applications where the algorithms do not control the distribution over the samples, but where the distributions are drawn from a "natural" distribution. Therefore, in this section we look at the even distribution and generally product distributions examined in the learning literature for combinatorial functions.

sections.heading: 4.1 Submodular functions with bounded curvature
sections.text: We consider submodular functions with limited curvature, a general assumption in the submodular maximization literature [27, 28, 40, 43]. We show that the Shapley value of these functions is roughly derivable from samples for which we derive a narrow limit. Intuitively, the curvature of a submodular function depends on how much the limit value of an element can decrease. This property is useful because the Shapley value of an element can be written as a weighted sum of its limit value contributions across all sectors. Definition 7. A monotonous submodular function C has a curvature [0, 1] if the CN\ {i} (i) is greater than the sum of its limit value contributions. This curvature is limited if it is used by all i.

sections.heading: 4.2 Learnability does not imply approximability of the Shapley value
sections.text: Although the Shapley value for the class of submodular functions with limited curvature is approximate, we show that the Shapley value of the coverage (and submodular) functions is not nearly derivable from the samples in general. Impossibility results are information theoretical and are not based on computational limitations. Coverage functions are an interesting class of functions because they are derived from samples of any distribution [3] according to the PMAC learning model [5], which is a generalization of PAC learning ability for real-world evaluated functions. In addition, coverage functions according to Theorem 1 have a Shapley value that can be efficiently approximated in the value quotation model.

sections.heading: 5 Data Dependent Shapley Value
sections.text: The general impossibility of calculating the Shapley value from random samples stems from the fact that the concept is geared to the query model, in which algorithms can be asked for the cost of any amount of S'N. In this section, we will develop an analogy that is data or distribution dependent, a value that can be described arbitrarily well in the statistical model for all functions. We start by specifying the four axioms that resemble the Shapley value. The data dependent axioms for cost distribution functions are: • Our proposed value is the unique solution that meets it.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion and Future Work
sections.text: Our results are divided into two categories: We provide results to approximate the Shapley value and the core area, and propose new cost-sharing concepts tailored to the statistical framework. We use techniques from several areas that include statistical machine learning, combinatorial optimization, and, of course, cost sharing. Since the cost-sharing literature is very rich, there is a significant number of future directions. One of the obvious possibilities is to study other methods of cost-sharing within this statistical framework, considering other classes of functions to approximate known methods, and improving the sample complexity of previous algorithms. Conceptually, there is an exciting modeling question when designing "desirable" axioms from data. Traditionally, these axioms have depended only on cost function, while in this model they may depend on both cost function and distribution, creating an interesting interplay.

metadata.abstractText: We study the cost sharing problem for cooperative games in situations where the cost function C is not available via oracle queries, but must instead be derived from data, represented as tuples (S,C(S)), for different subsets S of players. We formalize this approach, which we call STATISTICAL COST SHARING, and consider the computation of the core and the Shapley value, when the tuples are drawn from some distribution D. Previous work by Balcan et al. [8] in this setting showed how to compute cost shares that satisfy the core property with high probability for limited classes of functions. We expand on their work and give an algorithm that computes such cost shares for any function with a non-empty core. We complement these results by proving an inapproximability lower bound for a weaker relaxation. We then turn our attention to the Shapley value. We first show that when cost functions come from the family of submodular functions with bounded curvature, κ, the Shapley value can be approximated from samples up to a √ 1− κ factor, and that the bound is tight. We then define statistical analogues of the Shapley axioms, and derive a notion of statistical Shapley value. We show that these can always be approximated arbitrarily well for general functions over any distribution D. ∗School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, ericbalkanski@g.harvard.edu. †Google NYC, usyed@google.com. ‡Google NYC, sergeiv@google.com. 1 ar X iv :1 70 3. 03 11 1v 1 [ cs .G T ] 9 M ar 2 01 7
